verses.text: The allotment for the tribe of the people of Judah, according to their clans, reached southward to the border of Edom, to the wilderness of Zin at the farthest southern boundary.
verses.comment: This sets out the territory for Judah as per Numbers 34:3.

verses.text: Their south boundary began at the end of the Salt Sea, at the bay that faces southward,
verses.comment: Salt Sea refers to the Dead Sea.

verses.text: and it went out southward of the ascent of Akrabbim, passed along to Zin, and went up by the south of Kadesh-barnea, passed along Hezron, went up to Addar, and turned about to Karka.
verses.comment: This traces the southern border; Kadesh-barnea is near the Sinai Wilderness.

verses.text: It passed along to Azmon, went out by the Brook of Egypt, and ended at the sea. This shall be your southern border.
verses.comment: Brook of Egypt likely refers to Wadi el-Arish.

verses.text: The eastern border was the Salt Sea, as far as the mouth of the Jordan. The northern border began at the bay of the sea at the mouth of the Jordan.
verses.comment: Eastern boundary is the Dead Sea.

verses.text: And the boundary went up to Beth-hoglah, passed north of Beth-arabah. The border went up to the stone of Bohan the son of Reuben.
verses.comment: Stone of Bohan was a boundary marker.

verses.text: And the border went up to Debir from the Valley of Achor, then it turned north toward Gilgal, which is opposite the ascent of Adummim, which is south of the valley. Then the border passed along to the waters of En-shemesh and ended at En-rogel.
verses.comment: Place names unchanged for accuracy.

verses.text: Then the border went up by the Valley of the Son of Hinnom to the southern slope of the Jebusite city (that is, Jerusalem). The border went up to the top of the mountain that lies over the Valley of Hinnom, westward at the end of the Valley of Rephaim toward the north.
verses.comment: Explains that Jebusite city is Jerusalem.

verses.text: From the top of the mountain, the border curved to the spring of the waters of Nephtoah, went out to the cities of Mount Ephron. Then the border curved to Baalah (that is, Kiriath-jearim).
verses.comment: Kiriath-jearim is also called Baalah.

verses.text: The border turned from Baalah westward to Mount Seir, passed along to the northern slope of Mount Jearim (that is, Chesalon), went down to Beth-shemesh, and passed along by Timnah.
verses.comment: Place names maintained as in the original.

verses.text: The border went out to the northern slope of Ekron, turned to Shikkeron, passed along to Mount Baalah, went out to Jabneel, and ended at the sea.
verses.comment: Ends the western boundary at the Mediterranean.

verses.text: The western border was the Great Sea and its coastline. This is the boundary surrounding the people of Judah according to their clans.
verses.comment: Great Sea is the Mediterranean Sea.

verses.text: According to the commandment of the LORD to Joshua, he gave to Caleb the son of Jephunneh a portion among the people of Judah, Kiriath-arba (that is, Hebron). Arba was the father of Anak.
verses.comment: Kiriath-arba is explained to be Hebron in the text.

verses.text: And Caleb drove out from there the three sons of Anak: Sheshai, Ahiman, and Talmai, descendants of Anak.
verses.comment: Rephrased for clarity; the sons of Anak refers to giants.

verses.text: And he went up from there against the inhabitants of Debir. (Debir was formerly called Kiriath-sepher.)
verses.comment: Alternate name for Debir included.

verses.text: And Caleb said, 'Whoever strikes Kiriath-sepher and captures it, to him I will give Achsah my daughter as a wife.'
verses.comment: No significant difference from standard translations.

verses.text: And Othniel the son of Kenaz, Caleb's brother, captured it. So he gave him Achsah his daughter as a wife.
verses.comment: Family relationships emphasized as in the original.

verses.text: When she came to him, she persuaded him to ask her father for a field. So she got down from her donkey, and Caleb said to her, 'What do you want?'
verses.comment: Text follows original narrative.

verses.text: She said, 'Give me a blessing. Since you have given me land in the Negev, give me also springs of water.' So he gave her the upper springs and the lower springs.
verses.comment: The Negev refers to the dry southern region.

verses.text: This is the inheritance of the tribe of the people of Judah according to their clans.
verses.comment: Section break marking the list of towns.

verses.text: The cities at the extremity of the tribe of the people of Judah, toward the border of Edom in the Negev, were: Kabzeel, Eder, Jagur,
verses.comment: The term Negev used as in Hebrew.

verses.text: Kinah, Dimonah, Adadah,
verses.comment: Towns listed exactly as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: Kedesh, Hazor, Ithnan,
verses.comment: City names preserved.

verses.text: Ziph, Telem, Bealoth,
Hazor-hadattah, Kerioth-hezron (that is, Hazor),
verses.comment: Alternate name given for clarity.

verses.text: Amam, Shema, Moladah,
Hazar-gaddah, Heshmon, Beth-pelet,
Hazar-shual, Beersheba, Biziothiah,
verses.comment: Beersheba is a significant biblical location.

verses.text: Baalah, Iim, Ezem,
Eltolad, Chesil, Hormah,
Ziklag, Madmannah, Sansannah,
verses.comment: Ziklag is mentioned elsewhere as David's refuge.

verses.text: Lebaoth, Shilhim, Ain, and Rimmon; in all, twenty-nine cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Lists all cities in the Negev.

verses.text: In the lowland: Eshtaol, Zorah, Ashnah,
verses.comment: Shephelah is translated as 'lowland' for clarity.

verses.text: Zanoah, Engannim, Tappuah, Enam,
Jarmuth, Adullam, Socoh, Azekah,
verses.comment: Adullam appears in David's story.

verses.text: Shaaraim, Adithaim, Gederah, and Gederothaim; fourteen cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Number and naming as in original.

verses.text: Zenan, Hadashah, Migdal-gad,
Dilean, Mizpeh, Joktheel,
verses.comment: Mizpeh means 'watchtower'.

verses.text: Lachish, Bozkath, Eglon,
verses.comment: Lachish is well known from later biblical events.

verses.text: Cabbon, Lahmam, Chitlish,
Gederoth, Beth-dagon, Naamah, and Makkedah; sixteen cities with their villages.
Libnah, Ether, Ashan,
Iphtah, Ashnah, Nezib,
Keilah, Achzib, and Mareshah; nine cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Keilah is mentioned in the story of David.

verses.text: Ekron, with its towns and villages;
verses.comment: Ekron is a Philistine city.

verses.text: from Ekron to the sea, all that were near Ashdod, with their villages;
Ashdod, its towns and its villages; Gaza, its towns and its villages, as far as the Brook of Egypt and the Great Sea with its coastline.
verses.comment: Ashdod and Gaza are major Philistine cities.

verses.text: In the hill country: Shamir, Jattir, Socoh,
verses.comment: Begins hill country listing.

verses.text: Dannah, Kiriath-sannah (that is, Debir),
verses.comment: Alternate name explained parenthetically.

verses.text: Anab, Eshtemoh, Anim,
Goshen, Holon, and Giloh; eleven cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Number as in original.

verses.text: Arab, Dumah, Eshan,
Janum, Beth-tappuah, Aphekah,
Humtah, Kiriath-arba (that is, Hebron), and Zior; nine cities with their villages.
Maon, Carmel, Ziph, Juttah,
verses.comment: Carmel is not Mount Carmel in the north.

verses.text: Jezreel, Jokdeam, Zanoah,
Kain, Gibeah, and Timnah; ten cities with their villages.
Halhul, Beth-zur, Gedor,
Maarath, Beth-anoth, and Eltekon; six cities with their villages.
Kiriath-baal (that is, Kiriath-jearim), and Rabbah; two cities with their villages.
In the wilderness: Beth-arabah, Middin, Secacah,
verses.comment: Wilderness refers to the desert.

verses.text: Nibshan, the City of Salt, and En-gedi; six cities with their villages.
verses.comment: En-gedi is the oasis by the Dead Sea.

verses.text: But the people of Judah could not drive out the Jebusites who lived in Jerusalem. So to this day the Jebusites live with the people of Judah at Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Reflects the historical situation; see Judges 1:21.
